title: 110_hr853
content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings section of the Act highlights key information. The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods, there is a need for more public health professionals, only 6,000 physicians are board certified in preventive medicine, preventive medicine can help reduce costs spent on chronic conditions, the number of preventive medicine programs and professionals has decreased, preventive medicine physicians play a unique role in serving patients and communities, and a strong public health system relies on a strong preventive medicine workforce. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. Loan payment assistance of up to $20,000 is available for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. Physicians must submit an application to the Secretary of Health and Human Services to request this payment, which covers medical education loans incurred for the cost of attendance at a school. Authorization of appropriations is provided for loan payment assistance for preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. The assistance covers medical education loans incurred at a school of medicine. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section providing a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses for developing and implementing a qualified wellness program, with a maximum credit of $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must maintain accurate records of preventive services and programs. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes developing and implementing a program with health risk assessments and offering preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes annual counseling sessions and seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health for at least 50% of full-time employees. The term 'qualified employee' for an eligible employer refers to a full-time employee who is a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program. A 'qualified participant' is someone who engages in at least 2 annual preventive services and undergoes a health risk assessment during the taxable year. The eligible employer determines and implements a qualified wellness program during the taxable year. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. Amendments are made to section 38(b) and a new item is added to the table of sections. The Wellness Program Employer Credit under section 45O applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A new Wellness Program Participant Credit under section 25E is added to the Internal Revenue Code for nonrefundable personal credits. The Wellness Program Employer Credit under section 45O allows a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who are full-time employees participating in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by the wellness program. The Wellness Program Employer Credit under section 45O provides a $200 tax credit for qualified employees participating in a qualified wellness program developed and implemented by the employer. The program includes health risk assessments for participants. The Wellness Program Employer Credit offers a $200 tax credit for employees in a program that provides preventive services, counseling sessions, and seminars on various health topics. Qualified participants must meet specific criteria. The Wellness Program Employer Credit provides a $200 tax credit for eligible employers with a qualified wellness program that includes at least 50% of full-time employees. Eligible employers must develop and implement a wellness program and keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The Wellness Program Employer Credit offers a $200 tax credit for eligible employers with a qualified wellness program. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
